bibl.title: Military Orders for Walter Reed, July 18, 1890

div1.p: Sutherland asks Reed if a local physician can be employed to provide medical care to the garrison and Indian prisoners during Reed's leave of absence. The letter and military endorsements are dated from July 18, 1890 to August 18, 1890. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Walter Reed, July 18, 1890
div1.p:
1/878, MDO-Dd, 1890
3rd End.

Head Qts. Div. Alt. & Dept. East,
Gov. Isld., N.Y. July 18 1890

The Medical Director
1/7557 Da 1890
20 nd

Desires information as to whether
the services of a local physician
can be obtained at Mt. Vernon
Barracks, during the absence of
the Post Surgeon on leave.

Rec'd back M.D.O-Dd.
Aug 1. 1890.

First Indorsement.
Mount Vernon Bks., Ala.
July 29 '90

Respectfully returned
to the Medical Director.
The services of a local physician
can be obtained who, if necessary
is willing to occupy my quarters
and live in garrison during my
absence.

Walter Reed,
Captain, Apt. Surgeon, U.S.A.
Post Surgeon
E B 1/51

div1.head: Letter from Charles Sutherland to Walter Reed, July 18, 1890
div1.opener:
Headquarters Division of the Atlantic,
and Department of the East,
Medical Director's Office,
Governor's Island, N. Y., July 18, 1890.
Captain Walter Reed,
Assistant Surgeon U.S. Army,
Mount Vernon Barracks, Ala.
Sir:
div1.p:
Referring to your application for leave of absence, you are requested
to inform this office whether the services of a local physician, to be employed
by the visit under Paragraph 1636 of the Regulations, can be obtained to furnish
medical attendance to the garrison and the indian prisoners at your post.

The bill for the same is required to be made out in duplicate, and as
far as possible in accordance with the enclosed “Memorandum of instructions”,
and should not exceed the sum of One hundred and twenty five dollars [$125.00.]
per month.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully,
Your obedient servant, C Sutherland Col. & Surgeon U.S. Army,
Medical Director.
